awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Neuromodulation in the second near-infrared window
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the full complexity of the brain requires precisely manipulating the activity of specific neurons and observing their responses. One approach to manipulate neurons, which is termed “optogenetics”, uses visible light to activate light-sensitive ion channels on the cell membrane of neurons. Since visible light does not penetrate deep into the brain, this approach usually requires the invasive implantation of an optical fiber, which delivers light of desired wavelengths into the brain. The aim of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to improve the penetration depth of light for manipulating specific neurons in the brain, thus eliminating the need of an optical fiber and allowing the subject animal to behave freely. The results obtained from this project will enable noninvasive approaches to modulate brain activity through the intact scalp and skull. This project will also include research training opportunities for underrepresented minority (URM) high school students, with efforts to guide their pursuit of careers in STEM-related work.

Understanding neural computation requires causal manipulation of neural activity to dissect the complex circuit connections and the relationship between neural activity and certain behaviors. Optogenetics enable precise modulation of neural activity with millisecond temporal resolution and neuron-type specificity. Conventional optogenetics is performed in the visible spectrum; however, the delivery of visible light usually requires invasive implantation of an optical fiber into the brain, due to light attenuation (i.e., scattering and absorption) in cranial bone and brain tissue. This tethered fiber interface usually leads to acute tissue damage, chronic immune responses, and restriction of the subject’s free behavior. To address these challenges, the Investigator aims to investigate the feasibility of in vivo neuromodulation with light up to 1,500 nm in wavelength in the second near-infrared (NIR-II) spectrum. NIR-II light benefits from much reduced scattering and absorption compared to its visible counterpart, and it has been demonstrated to enable deep-brain imaging through the intact scalp and skull in mice. The Research Plan is organized under three objectives: (1) Synthesize biocompatible polymers with NIR-II absorption in the range of 1,000~1,500 nm; (2) Target NIR-light sensitive transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) ion channels in dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons with NIR-II absorbing polymers for in-vitro neuromodulation; and (3) Demonstrate the feasibility of NIR-II neuromodulation in the mouse hippocampus through the intact scalp and skull. The knowledge gained from this project will shed light on the feasibility of optogenetic neuromodulation in the NIR-II window and thus offer more guidance on NIR-II light-based approaches in biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Supported by the EAGER grant (Award ID: 2217582), our research has focused on exploring the interaction of biological tissues with light across the visible (400-700 nm), near-infrared (NIR, 700-1000 nm), and short-wave infrared (SWIR, also known as NIR-II, 1000-3000 nm) spectra. We specifically aimed to leverage the reduced light scattering in the NIR-II spectrum and explored strategies to minimize the intrinsic scattering of biological tissues, thereby enhancing imaging and modulation of biological activity in deep-seated structures such as the brain and gut.

Our work capitalized on the inversely proportional relationship between light wavelength and the scattering coefficients of biological tissues, enabling deep-brain neuromodulation in freely behaving animals. Compared to visible light, NIR and SWIR light exhibit significantly reduced scattering, allowing for much deeper tissue penetration. We developed molecules that either can be synthesized in the lab and rendered biocompatible through amphiphilic coating or encoded via genetic approaches to be produced by biological tissues themselves. These molecules, with strong absorption in the NIR-II spectrum, enabled region-specific and cell-type-specific neuromodulation in the deep brain of behaving mice, even as the incident light penetrated through intact scalp and skull. We validated the efficacy and specificity of our approach through in-situ electrophysiological recordings, mouse behavioral experiments, and immunostaining of brain slices.

We also posed a critical question from our findings in this project: rather than relying solely on the reduced scattering of light at longer wavelengths, can we intrinsically reduce the scattering of biological tissues across the entire visible, NIR, and SWIR (NIR-II) spectra? This grant facilitated a collaboration with the Brongersma Lab at Stanford, where we discovered that the intrinsic scattering of biological tissues arises from the heterogeneous distribution of refractive indices at the microscopic level (e.g., aqueous cytosol vs. lipid membrane). Most importantly, we found that the differences in refractive index are due to varying absorption properties in the deep UV spectrum. This led to a counterintuitive breakthrough: by increasing the absorption of water through the dissolution of specific dye molecules, we can match its refractive index with that of lipids and proteins. This eliminates the heterogeneous distribution of refractive indices at the microscopic scale, thereby reducing scattering and making biological tissues transparent across the visible, NIR, and SWIR (NIR-II) spectra.

In summary, the EAGER grant has not only enabled the completion of the proposed project but has also led to significant advancements beyond the original scope, driven by unique findings. These findings have culminated in several key publications, including E. L. Schmidt, et al. in Nature Reviews Methods Primers, 2024, 4, 23 and Z. Ou, et al. in Science, 2024, in press.
